name: untitled (shimmer, plus)  [print]
description: untitled (shimmer, plus) 2012_04_21 pigment ink print on 100% cotton rag paper 8 1/2" x 11" (21.59 x 27.94)cm open edition Offered as an affordable, open edition inkjet print signed in graphite by the artist, Matt Niebuhr. Each print is printed and signed by the artist, offered on Hahnemuhle, smooth Photo Rag - 100% cotton paper - archive quality. The print image is 7" x 9" with minimum of 1/2" white border all sides - suitable for framing in a standard 8" x 10" frame. Print is shipped flat in a protective sleeve and stiff cardboard mailer. Also available is the unique, original work on paper: untitled (shimmer, plus) oil pastel and graphite on paper 18" x 23 3/8" (45.7 x 59.4)cm Matt Niebuhr www.mattniebuhr.com See also a sampling of other work posted on my tumblr drawing log: Matt Niebuhr - Drawings (top: original drawing) (middle: drawing detail) (bottom: print edition)

name: untitled ( lines "y" 128 diagonals) on polyester film
description: untitled ( lines "y" 128 diagonals) 2011_02_05 graphite on polyester drafting film 42" x 42" (106.68 x 106.68)cm Matt Niebuhr Custom framed original drawing - ready to hang. Frame is baltic birch finished in bee's wax with archival mounting and acrylic glazing, frame is hand made by the artist - Matt Niebuhr. See more details about custom framing. Notes: A wonderful thing about drawing a line is that it can be any number of things. One line is not necessarily any more important or informative than any other line, but it can be assigned a representative value, it can become important, it can become symbolic. Strictly speaking, a line is a geometrical object that is straight, infinitely long and infinitely thin. A line is one-dimensional. It has zero width (in mathematics). If you draw a line with a pencil, the pencil mark has a measurable width. The pencil line is in some ways just a means to illustrate the idea of a line on paper. The line drawn on paper is always only at first, just a representation of the idea of a line. In this sense, we can really only imagine the idea of a line, it can not be seen with our eyes directly, but indirectly, as an approximate representation. A line as an idea drawn, is I think, a beautiful thing in all of its imperfect representation. (top: overall drawing) (middle / bottom: installed custom frame)

name: untitled,   (lines "y" 1 diagonal)
description: untitled, (lines "y" 1 diagonal) 2011_04_05 graphite on gesso on wood 24" x 24" (60.96 x 60.96)cm Matt Niebuhr "... exploring of the idea of line, I am interested in the accumulation of lines that may depending upon arrangement take on other qualities. The Lines "y" series are tools. Tools are objects in service to create something else. A line is like a wrench is a tool, meaning that it is a device manipulated by the hand and used by a mechanic, plumber, carpenter, or other laborer to work, shape, move, or transform material… In the case of the artist, the line is a tool put in service to shape experience." - Matt Niebuhr Offered as an original painting, signed and dated verso, custom mounting on back, ready for hanging. (top: overall painting) (middle: detail) (bottom: painting installed)

description: untitled, #4 lines, black and white on grey 2011_03_27 ink and graphite, acrylic on wood 24” x 24” (60.96 x 60.96)cm Matt Niebuhr "... there is something interesting about the struggle between the idea of perfection and the reality of imperfection. I think it is the touch of the hand which fascinates the mind..." Matt Niebuhr Offered as an original painting, signed and dated verso, custom mounting on back, ready for hanging.
